repnme.cdata!:
Lesotho - Agricultural Policy and Capacity
            Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was unsatisfactory, the sustainability
            was likely, the institutional development impact was modest,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and borrower
            performance was unsatisfactory,. The lessons learned
            indicate that the lack of core measurable outcome indicators
            can detract implementation activities from core objectives
            with the danger of becoming more narrowly focused on
            implementation of component outputs rather than on overall
            project development outcomes. The simpler the project the
            easier the implementation. There is often a danger of
            designing a project which requires capacity levels far
            higher than exists in the beneficiary country with the
            assumption that it will be built up during the project.
            Delaying design issues for project implementation simply
            delays implementation and impact. Policy change is often
            politically sensitive, with the losers of policy change
            often the more powerful and well connected, hence arguments
            for change need to be clear and convincing with broad
            consultation to ensure reform and to prevent reversal. The
            relatively limited potential of agriculture in Lesotho,
            particularly in its contribution to overall economic growth,
            should be clearly recognized in the development objectives
            of future programs. A clear monitoring framework to guide
            decisions on project restructuring should be established,
            with continued management oversight.

repnme.cdata!:
Lesotho - Agricultural Policy and Capacity
            Building Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Agricultural Policy and Capacity
            Building aims at introducing improved institutional and
            policy arrangements for the sustainable and efficient
            management, financing, and delivery of public and private
            agricultural services. There are four main project
            components. First, the sector strategy and management
            component will strengthen analytical capacity for essential
            policy analysis, build skills and technical expertise in
            sectoral planning, develop a monitoring and evaluation
            system, and introduce a management information system.
            Second, the agricultural support services component will
            address the core functions of the Ministry of Agriculture.
            It will increase the effectiveness of the agricultural
            service delivery system in all 10 districts in Lesotho.
            Third, the land management and administration component will
            facilitate land policy review, legal and administrative
            reforms, and institutional strengthening. Fourth, the change
            process management component will focus on institutional
            reforms and developing related policies and systems.

repnme.cdata!:
Lesotho - Agricultural Policy and Capacity
            Building Project (APCBP) : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental assessment for
            the Agricultural Policy and Capacity Building Project, which
            puts in place policy arrangements providing food security,
            creating jobs, and increasing private participation.
            Although the overall project impact is anticipated to be
            environmentally positive, various hazards on the physical
            environment could be exacerbated and contribute further to
            reduced vegetative cover, which in turn leads to increased
            run-off, soil erosion, formation of gullies and
            "dongas," land degradation, and loss of
            biodiversity. Activities could also compound the devastating
            effects of periodic droughts and desertification on
            agricultural production. Hence, mitigation measures must be
            inter-related: Soil erosion will be controlled by planting
            vegetation and using mechanical measures to intercept runoff
            (on a catchment basis). Land conservation will restrict
            cultivation to suitable sites, control livestock on communal
            grazing land, and introduce mandatory dipping and
            de-worming. Forming and empowering range management
            associations, improving livestock quality, and
            infrastructure and inputs are needed. The customary
            provision discouraging long fallow encourages desultory
            land-use practices, inimical to conservation, points to the
            need to engage nongovernmental organizations in awareness
            building, education, and protection. Agricultural chemicals
            should be limited and small-scale irrigation preferred to
            large-scale systems.
